ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: They were beside a road which still exists.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_1: This (city) lies on a road that still survives.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: The place (where this occurred) lies along a known route.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: That town lies on a road which still exists.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: And indeed that township is upon a road still in use.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: And verily, they were right on the highroad.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: And surely it is on a road that still abides.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_7: surely it is on a way yet remaining;
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: And lo! it is upon a road still uneffaced.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_9: it is still there on the highway --
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: And verily they are on a pathway lasting.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: Indeed it is on a standing road,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: And the (cities were) right on the high-road.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: And verily! They (the cities) were right on the highroad (from Makkah to Syria i.e. the place where the Dead Sea is now).
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: Indeed, it is on a way which still exists.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: And it is on an existing road.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: And indeed, those cities are [situated] on an established road.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [15:76] And indeed they, that is, the cities of the people of Lot, are on a road that [still] remains, Quraysh’s route to Syria, [one] not yet effaced: so why do they not take heed from their example?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: And lo! It) i.e. the township of Lot (is upon a road still uneffaced) a road that they pass by all the time.
